Porous ZnO−TiO2 synthesized using different Zn and Ti ratios (Zn:Ti = 0.5, 1, 2) is investigated as PdZn alloy support to optimize methanol production from CO2 hydrogenation. XRD, Raman, and XPS analyses reveal that varying Zn ratios influence crystal structure, oxygen vacancies, surface area and ZnTiO3 phases. The partial transformation into ZnTiO3 occurs on the PdZn perimeter, forming strong interfacial interaction with the PdZn alloy. Higher Zn content promotes hexagonal ZnTiO3, while lower ratios favor cubic ZnTiO3, which leads to higher oxygen vacancy formation. High methanol selectivity was obtained below 250 °C with optimum productivity at ∼1326.8 mmolkgcat -1h-1. CO is the main product at temperatures above 250 °C, while methane and C2+hydrocarbons from the C − C coupling reaction occur at 450 °C. In-situ DRIFTS analysis provides insight into the reaction mechanism that requires stabilization of formate *HCOO and formyl species, *HCO, for hydrogenation to methanol. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords PdZn alloy CO2 hydrogenation Methanol ZnTiO3 interface Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Carbon dioxide in the atmosphere has reached an alarming level and, therefore, requires a global effort to prevent catastrophic consequences. The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) advised that limiting global warming to 1.5 °C instead of 2 °C might mitigate extreme climate change [1]. CO2 captured from various industries can be utilized as a renewable carbon source [2]. Carbon capture and utilization (CCU) in carbon management addressed both emission-control and energy-supply limitations compared to carbon capture and storage (CCS) [3]. CO2 hydrogenation to methanol (CTM) is one of the CCU technologies offering easy storage and transportation of liquid methanol [4]. CTM is an exothermic reaction releasing -49.5 kJmol-1 of energy at 298 K (Eqn. (1)). The reaction thermodynamically favored low temperature and high pressure conditions [5]. (1) C O 2 + 3 H 2 ⇌ C H 3 OH + H 2 O , Δ H 298 K o = − 49 . 5 kJmo l − 1 (2) C O 2 + H 2 ⇌ CO + H 2 O , Δ H 298 K o = + 41 . 2 kJmo l − 1 However, the selective formation of methanol from CO2 is a challenging process due to the high activation energy and the competing reverse-water-gas-shift reaction (RWGS)(Eqn. (2)) [6]. The ternary Cu−ZnO−Al2O3 (CZA) catalysts are commonly used in the industry for the production of methanol but rather exclusively from syngas (CO/CO2/H2) operating at pressure 50–100 bar and reaction temperature 200−300 °C [7,8],. Despite its high activity via syngas conversion, CZA displayed poor catalytic activity over direct CO2 hydrogenation due to surface oxidation and particle sintering of the active Cu/Zn sites [9,10],. As a promoter in Cu/ZnO catalysts for methanol synthesis, Pd sustained the reduced state of Cu via hydrogen spillover [11]. Pd-based catalysts were more resistant to particle sintering than Cu-based catalysts [12,13],. Apart from the active metal sites that catalyze hydrogenation, metal oxide support is also crucial for generating strong metal-support interaction, increasing surface oxygen vacancies and providing sites for CO2 adsorption [14]. Electron transfer efficiency between metal and supports promotes hydrogen dissociation [15]. The strong metal support interaction between Cu and ZnO improved electron transfer and enhanced CO2 adsorption sites [16]. However, due to prolonged hydrogenation, metal oxide support also suffers structural arrangement during the catalytic reaction. Several metal oxides have been utilized as Pd support in the CO2 hydrogenation to methanol, creating various Pd-based active phases. Pd on support such as ZnO and Ga2O3 displayed higher activity and selectivity towards methanol at mild temperature and high pressure, with apparent Pd alloying to PdZn or PdGa, respectively [17-18],. The alloy provides active sites for stabilizing the formate intermediate during CO2 hydrogenation to methanol [19]. Employing ZnO as support resulted in a high dispersion of Pd, while ZnO served as a hydrogen reservoir [20,21],. Previous literature reported that Pd on TiO2 support demonstrated extensively high activity for methanol synthesis from syngas conversion due to strong-metal-support interaction (SMSI) [22,23],. TiO2 may hinder the RWGS, producing maximum methanol selectivity [24]. In the CO oxidative coupling reaction, strong interaction between Pd and cubic phase ZnTiO3 formed enriched Pd electronic density, promoting the bridge CO adsorption [25]. ZnTiO3 exhibits higher oxygen vacancy defects than ZnO and TiO2 from the tetrahedral cation arrangement Ti3+−OH, which is also referred to as octahedral oxygen vacancies. Oxygen vacancies are more developed in the cubic phase ZnTiO3 than in the hexagonal structure [26]. PdZn/ZnTiO3 catalysts were reported to improve methanol selectivity and yield and inhibit CH4 formation [27]. In this work, a series of ZnO−TiO2_x, where x represented different Zn to Ti molar ratios (x = Zn/Ti = 0.5, 1.0 and 2.0), was synthesized using evaporation induced self-assembly (EISA) method followed by hydrothermal treatment. The use of organic templates Pluronic aims to introduce porosity within the crystallite structures of ZnO/TiO2 and improve surface area. The Zn/Ti ratios were varied to investigate the effect of transformation to ZnTiO3 on the evolution of surface oxygen vacancies. PdZn were deposited on ZnO−TiO2_x using chemical vapor impregnation to avoid surface contamination caused by solvent usage [27] and to ensure high metal dispersion onto the support [28,29],. The changes in the crystal structure and morphology of the catalysts, the surface oxygen vacancies and the physiochemical properties will be monitored to understand the effect on methanol production. In-situ DRIFTS analysis was performed to study the reaction mechanism at different temperatures during CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of ZnO−TiO2 support Materials used in synthesizing ZnO−TiO2 were zinc (II) nitrate hexahydrate (Zn(NO3)2·6H2O, Sigma-Aldrich, 98%) and titanium butoxide (Ti(OBu)4, Sigma-Aldrich, 97%) as Zn and Ti precursors. The synthesis employed evaporation-induced self-assembly (EISA) and subsequent hydrothermal treatment [30] at different Zn to Ti ratios, ZnO−TiO2_x, where x = Zn/Ti molar ratio (0.5, 1.0, 2.0). Pluronic F127 (Sigma-Aldrich) was used in the EISA method as the structure directing agent without additional acid or base. 0.8 g of Pluronic F127 was first dissolved in 20 mL of ethanol at room temperature. Zn and Ti precursors were added to the solution, covered with parafilm and stirred vigorously for 5 h at room temperature. The slurry produced was transferred into an autoclave and underwent overnight hydrothermal treatment at 120 °C. Afterward, the slurry was centrifuged to obtain the precipitate. The precipitate was filtered and washed with ethanol, which was then dried in an oven at 100 °C for 24 h to remove the remaining solvent. Calcination was done at 600 °C in an air atmosphere with a slow ramp rate (5 °Cmin-1) to ensure the mesoporous structure. 2.2 Catalyst preparation PdZn catalysts were prepared using chemical vapor impregnation. Palladium (II) acetylacetonate (Pd(acac)2, Aldrich, 99%) and zinc acetylacetonate (Zn(acac)2, Sigma-Aldrich) were used as metal precursors. Composite ZnO−TiO2 with different Zn:Ti ratios were used to support PdZn catalysts. The amount of Pd and Zn were kept at 3% relative to the weight of ZnO−TiO2 support. The amount of Pd and Zn were chosen based on previously reported studies [31]. The precursors and ZnO−TiO2_x were weighed accordingly, placed in a vial, and shaken vigorously for 30 s. The mixture was transferred into a Schlenk flask, and the flask was connected to a vacuum pump via a Schlenk line, evacuated at room temperature with pressure ∼10–3 mbar and heated up to 145 °C for 1 h. The PdZn/ZnO−TiO2_x catalysts were calcined in an air atmosphere at 500 °C for 6 h with a ramp rate of 5 °Cmin-1 to remove the organic precursors. 2.3 Characterization Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) was done using Shimadzu XRD-700 X-ray Diffractometer equipped with Cu-Kα radiation at λ = 1.54 Å with scanning angle range between 20 and 60° with a scan rate of 1°min-1. Diffraction patterns were identified using Xpert Highscore Plus utilizing International Center for Diffraction database (ICDD). Scherrer's Equation (Eqn. (3)) was employed to calculate PdZn crystallite size. (3) D = k λ β cos θ Where D is the crystallite size (nm), k is the Scherrer's constant (0.9), λ is the wavelength of x-ray (0.15406 nm), β is the full-width-half-maximum (radians) and θ is the peak position (radians). Raman spectra of calcined ZnO−TiO2_x and PdZn/ZnO−TiO2_x were obtained using Scanner 5.0 Raman system with 532 nm wavelength laser. Micrometrics ASAP 2020 was used to examine the textural properties of ZnO−TiO2_x and PdZn/ ZnO−TiO2_x where the specific surface area was calculated using the BET method and both pore volume and diameter were calculated using the BJH method. 200 mg of catalyst was placed inside sample tube and degassed at 300 °C for 2 h under vacuum prior to analysis. High resolution transmission electron microscope (HR-TEM) (Tecnai G2 F20 S TWIN) at 200 kV was utilized to study the morphology of PdZn/ZnO−TiO2_x at micro- and nanoscales resolution. Reducibility of the PdZn catalysts was investigated using Quantachrome ChemBET Pulsar TPR/TPD equipped with thermal conductivity detector (TCD). 40 mg of catalyst was transferred into a u-quartz tube, which was later connected to the gas port. The catalyst underwent pre-treatment under N2 flow at 100 °C with a flow rate of 75 mLmin-1 for 1 h and then the catalyst was cooled down to 25 °C. Afterward, 5%H2/N2 gas was introduced into the reactor at the same flow rate and heated up to 1050 °C with a ramp rate of 5 °Cmin-1 to obtain the H2-TPR profile. CO2 temperature-programmed desorption was performed with the same instrument as H2-TPR to evaluate surface basicity and CO2 adsorption capacity during CO2 hydrogenation. PdZn catalysts were reduced in 5%H2/N2 gas at 600 °C for 1 h and later cooled down to 40 °C under He flow. The catalyst was subjected to CO2 gas for 30 min and flushed out with He for 1 h. CO2 desorption was performed from 40 to 600 °C with a ramp rate of 10 °Cmin-1. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy was conducted for PdZn/ZnO−TiO2_x using Kratos Axis Ultra-DLD XPS Spectrometer with a monochromatic Al Kα source (75−150 mW). The XPS spectra acquired were analyzed using CASA XPS software and calibrated by adjusting C1s position to 284.5 eV. The deconvolution of Pd 3d and O 1 s peaks were constructed from Gaussian/Lorentzian line-shapes. The chemical states of elements were identified based on the broadening of the peak, while Relative Sensitivity Factors (RSF) were used for elemental quantification [32]. In-situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) was done to identify surface intermediates during CO2 hydrogenation. This was done in Shimadzu IRTracer-100 infrared spectrometer equipped with a Specac high temperature high pressure (HTHP) cell. 50 mg of catalyst was pelletized and placed in the HTHP cell, which was reduced in situ at 400 °C with flow rate of 10 mLmin-1 for 1 h. The catalyst was cooled down to room temperature and 1CO2:4H2:1N2 gas mixture was introduced to the flow of 10 mLmin-1 with temperature range 200−400 °C and pressurized at 15 bar. IR spectra were recorded at each temperature at 30 min intervals with 45 scans and a resolution of 4 cm-1 from 4000−100 cm-1. 2.4 Catalytic activity CO2 hydrogenation to methanol was conducted in a tubular plug flow reactor (PFR) at reaction temperature ranging from 200−400 °C and a pressure of 20 bar. 0.5 g of catalyst was placed in the reactor and reduced in situ with 30 mLmin-1 of H2 at 400 °C for 1 h. The catalyst was cooled down to room temperature and a mixture of 1CO2:4H2:1N2 gases at 30 mLmin-1 was introduced into the reactor. The back pressure regulator was used to achieve 20 bar. Effluent reaction lines and valves were heated to prevent product condensation. The products from the reactor were analyzed by Shimadzu GC-2014C equipped with thermal conductivity detector (TCD) for permanent gas detection and flame ionization detector (FID) for analyzing methanol and higher hydrocarbons. CO2 conversion (Eqn. (4)) and product selectivity (Eqn. (5)) were calculated using N2 as an internal standard. (4) x C O 2 ( % ) = n C O 2 , i n − n C O 2 , o u t n C O 2 , i n × 100 % (5) S P * ( % ) = n P ∑ n t o t a l p r o d u c t s × 100 % Where x C O 2 (%) is the conversion of CO2, S P * (%) product selectivity, n P is the number of moles of product, n C O 2 , i n is the number of moles of CO2 at the inlet, n C O 2 , o u t is the number of moles of CO2 at the outlet. *(P = CH3OH/CO/CH4) 3 Results and discussion 3.1 N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms The textural properties of calcined ZnO−TiO2_x and PdZn/ ZnO−TiO2_x were investigated by conducting N2 adsorption-desorption analysis (Fig 1 ). Based on IUPAC classification, ZnO−TiO2_1.0 and ZnO−TiO2_2.0 demonstrated Type IV with H1 hysteresis loops associated with mesoporous materials with well-defined cylindrical pores or accumulation of uniform spheres [33]. ZnO−TiO2_0.5 showed a Type V isotherm with an H3 hysteresis loop, indicating mesoporous structures but with slit-shaped pores. However, the open hysteresis loops were due to the instability of the micro/mesoporous structure that caused the adsorbate gas not to fully desorb during analysis as the relative pressure (P/Po) decreased. Upon PdZn impregnation, there is a slight change in isotherm classification for PdZn/ZnO−TiO2_1.0 as it displayed Type V isotherm, which still signified mesoporous structure but with a narrow H3 hysteresis loop. The isotherms and hysteresis loops for PdZn/ ZnO−TiO2_x with 0.5 and 2 ratios remained the same as the unimpregnated ZnO−TiO2_x. From the pore size distribution graphs in Fig 1.(b) and Table 1 , all the catalysts displayed an average mesopore diameter of ∼ 2 nm and a large mesopore of ∼23 nm, confirming the mesoporous structure from the isotherms. BET surface area of ZnO−TiO2_x and PdZn/ZnO−TiO2_x are summarized in Table 1. Visible alteration in SBET could be observed upon impregnation of PdZn onto ZnO−TiO2_x. As for ZnO−TiO2_1.0, its SBET reduced after PdZn impregnation from 42 to 33 m2g-1 due to partial conversion of titania to cubic crystalline ZnTiO3 (c-ZnTiO3) as observed in XRD [27,34],. Similar behavior cannot be established for PdZn/ZnO−TiO2_0.5 and PdZn/ZnO−TiO2_2.0, as the former showed increased BET surface area. PdO nanoparticles might be well-dispersed on the external surface, resulting in no apparent change in surface area. 3.2 XRD analysis Fig 2 . (a) displayed XRD patterns of ZnO−TiO2_x after calcination in air at 600 °C for 4 h. All ZnO−TiO2_x demonstrated diffraction peaks at 2θ = 25.5°, 37.9°, 48.3° and 55.1° indexed at (101), (004), (200) and (211) planes corresponded to anatase TiO2 (JCPDS 073–1764). Rutile TiO2 (JCPDS 078–1510) phase was identified at 2θ = 27.7° (110) and 54.2° (211) for all ZnO−TiO2_x with additional peak formed at 41.3° (111) specifically for ZnO−TiO2_0.5. Different phases of ZnTiO3 can be identified on the XRD; the c-ZnTiO3 peak formed at 2θ = 30.2° indexed at (220) corresponded to cubic structure of ZnTiO3 (JCPDS 039–0190) whereas h-ZnTiO3 peaks can be seen at 2θ = 32.9° (104) and 49.1° (024) related to the hexagonal crystal structure (JCPDS 025–0671). There is an additional peak at 2θ = 40.6° indexed as (113) plane corresponding to h-ZnTiO3, suggesting that Zn:Ti = 2.0 favored the formation of the hexagonal ZnTiO3. Hexagonal ZnO (JCPDS 075–1533) peak was also observed on all ZnO−TiO2_x diffractograms at 2θ = 35.5° relative to the (101) plane. ZnO crystallite size was calculated using Scherrer's equation (Eqn. (3) based on the (101) plane on X'pert Highscore. From Table 2 , we can see that the crystallite size of ZnO became larger as the Zn:Ti ratio increased in the ZnO−TiO2, suggesting that Ti loading constricted the growth of ZnO during synthesis. The presence of anatase/rutile TiO2 and ZnO implied that the calcination temperature at 500 °C formed composite Zn−Ti oxides, with slight growth of ZnTiO3. Another XRD analysis was performed for PdZn/ZnO−TiO2_x after reduction at 400 °C (Fig 2.(b)) to establish the formation of PdZn alloy. Formation of cubic metallic Pd (JCPDS 002–1439) upon reduction of PdZn/ZnO−TiO2 catalysts can be confirmed by the diffraction peak formed at 2θ = 40.8° (111) (Fig 2.(b)) and peaks developed at 2θ = 41.4° (111) and 44.1° (200) showed the formation of PdZn alloy (JCPDS 006–0620) after undergoing reduction. Hydrogen spillover on reduced Pd separates ZnO within the perimeter, which resulted in segregated Zn to be incorporated into the metallic Pd lattice to form PdZn alloy. PdZn alloy is the active phase for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol [35–37],. The segregation of ZnO can be proven by the peak at 2θ = 35.5°shift to a higher diffraction angle (Fig 2.c) after reduction, suggesting lattice strain from Ti2+ incorporation into ZnO lattice, which led to c-ZnTiO3 formation. However, the shift is less apparent on PdZn/ZnO−TiO2_1.0, as the ZnO diffraction peak remained at 2θ = 35.5. PdZn crystallite size was calculated based on (111) and (200) planes and estimated to be in the range of 24.5–45.5 nm. 3.3 Raman spectroscopy Fig 3 . (a) displayed Raman spectra of ZnO−TiO2_x after calcination in air at 600 °C for 4 h. The major band formed at 154 cm-1 corresponded to symmetric stretching of Ti−O−Ti bonds with Eg Raman mode, which could be assigned to anatase TiO2 on all ZnO−TiO2_x. The bands formed at 406 cm-1 (B1 g), 528 cm-1 (A1 g/B1 g) and 650 cm-1 (Eg) corresponded to symmetric bending vibrations of the same titania phase [38]. The absence of Raman bands associated with rutile TiO2 signified a low concentration of rutile. ZnO could not be observed on the Raman spectra of ZnO−TiO2_x despite moderate ZnO crystallite size calculated based on XRD results, presumably due to the heterogeneous dispersion of ZnO on TiO2. Another Raman spectroscopy was done to elucidate intensity and vibrational mode changes upon PdZn impregnation onto the ZnO−TiO2 support. Note that metallic palladium, Pd0, is Raman inactive. Fig 3.(b) also confirms the formation of oxygen vacancies from the shift of the Raman bands from 154 cm-1 to 159 cm-1, 165 cm-1 and 161 cm-1 for PdZn/ZnO−TiO2_1.0, PdZn/ZnO−TiO2_0.5 and PdZn/ZnO−TiO2_2.0 respectively [39]. The reduced intensity following PdZn formation also suggests increased oxygen vacancies in the lattice. The oxygen vacancies changed the atomic coordination number and the bonding length of the Ti-O-Ti network. In ZnO−TiO2 porous support, ZnTiO3 formation induces higher oxygen vacancies from the terminal Ti3+−OH bond. The peak broadening also indicates the formation of oxygen vacancies due to lattice disorder from non-stoichiometric TiO2 [40]. The broadening and reduced peak intensity are more apparent on lower Zn:Ti ratios, implying higher oxygen vacancies on PdZn catalysts deposited at less ZnO composition than TiO2. 3.4 Morphology analysis FESEM analysis determined the morphology and interparticle porosity of the calcined PdZn/ZnO−TiO2_x (Fig 4 ). PdZn/ZnO−TiO2_x exhibited diverse morphology that generated inter-particle porosity with respect to their different Zn:Ti ratios. PdZn/ZnO−TiO2_0.5 represented spherical-like crystallites at ∼ 1–2 μm size. The formation of elongated cubic ZnTiO3 can be clearly distinguished from the SEM image. The cubic crystallites were connected, forming tunnel-like network with the spherical crystallites. PdZn/ZnO−TiO2_1.0 represented bulky micro-spherical clusters that can be attributed to TiO2 particles. However, the formation of ZnTiO3 cannot be distinguished from TiO2. The hexagonal structure of ZnTiO3 is more apparent at Zn:Ti = 2.0, suggesting a high Zn ratio promoted h-ZnTiO3 formation. In general, ZnTiO3 was formed at temperatures higher than 700 °C due to enhanced atomic mobility [41]. However, varying Zn:Ti ratios have affected ZnTiO3 growth at temperatures below 700 °C. On PdZn/ZnO−TiO2_2.0, the crystallites appeared as a mixture of micro-spherical, elongated cubic and deformed hexagonal crystallites. TEM microscopy revealed homogeneous dispersion of PdZn nanoparticles on the support as observed on the TEM image of PdZn/ZnO−TiO2_1.0 (Fig 5 .(a)). The average PdZn particle diameter was estimated at 5.5 nm. HRTEM microscopy was also used to determine the interplanar spacing of different phases of the catalyst. In Fig 5.(b), the interplanar spacing of anatase TiO2 is 0.350 nm, corresponding to the (101) plane [42]. The lattice spacing was determined at 0.218 nm relative to the crystal PdZn (200) plane, which confirmed the formation of PdZn alloy upon reduction. The presence of c-ZnTiO3 (311) with an interplanar spacing of 0.249 nm could be observed near PdZn [43]. This signifies the formation of strong PdZn/ZnTiO3 interfacial interaction that developed following the formation of PdZn alloy [44]. 3.5 H2-TPR analysis H2-TPR investigated the effect of the different Zn:Ti ratios on the reducibility of the catalysts (Fig 6 .(a)). The negative peaks formed between 40−80 °C on all reduction profiles of PdZn/ZnO−TiO2_x corresponded to the discharge of hydrogen gas due to the decomposition of palladium hydride (PdH x ) from the Pd surface [45]. PdH x is an unstable species that disintegrates gradually at temperatures below 100 °C, releasing hydrogen as a negative peak [46]. The H2-TPR profile of PdZn/ZnO−TiO2_2.0 displayed a reduction peak at 98 °C ascribed to the reduction of PdO nanoparticles [47,48],. A small reduction peak centered at 237 °C as seen in PdZn/ZnO−TiO2_0.5, demonstrated PdO nanoparticles are well-dispersed onto the support, signifying strong-metal-support-interaction (SMSI) [26,49],. Broad, shoulder peaks between 350−500 °C could be assigned to both bulk ZnO partial reduction and surface TiO2 reduction. As ZnO could only be moderately reduced to Zn at ∼600 °C [50], bulk ZnO [44,49], was partially reduced at a lower reduction temperature between 300−400 °C due to the hydrogen spillover provided by metallic Pd nanoparticles thus producing PdZn alloy [51]. The results are aligned with the XRD data that shows PdZn alloy formation after reduction at 400 °C. A reduction in temperature between 400−500 °C could be ascribed to surface TiO2 reduction in the presence of ZnO to form ZnTiO3 [52]. The continuous hydrogen uptake at temperatures above 450 °C suggests a gradual transformation of ZnO and TiO2 to ZnTiO3. A small reduction peak centered at 800 °C could be assigned to complete the transformation of ZnO and TiO2 to ZnTiO3 [26]. The formation of ZnTiO3 depends on Zn:Ti ratios, as indicated in XRD. For PdZn/ZnO−TiO2_0.5, the ZnTiO3 formed at temperatures lower than PdZn/ZnO−TiO2_1.0 and PdZn/ZnO−TiO2_2.0. 3.6 CO2-TPD analysis CO2-TPD was performed to evaluate the surface basicity and basic site distribution of the PdZn/ZnO−TiO2 catalysts, as seen in Fig 6.(b). The broad desorption peaks formed between 100 and 350 °C in PdZn/ZnO-TiO2_0.5 indicate multiple CO2 interactions with moderate basic sites on Zn-Ti oxides. Adsorbed CO2 formed carbonate species via interaction with oxygen vacancy on the surface of the support [53]. However, as the Zn:Ti ratio increased, the desorption peaks started to be slightly refined, which is more apparent in PdZn/ZnO_TiO2_2.0, suggesting the amount of Zn affected the basicity and CO2 desorption. The amount of CO2 desorbed was calculated by deconvoluting the desorption peaks and summarized in Table 3 . The amount of CO2 desorbed for the PdZn catalysts varied between 12 and 20 μmolgcat -1 with PdZn/ZnO−TiO2_1.0 providing the most basic sites as it demonstrated the highest CO2 desorption of 12.0 μmolgcat -1 which will enhance methanol formation during catalytic reaction. 3.7 XPS analysis XPS was used to analyze the surface composition and oxidation states of the calcined and spent PdZn/ZnO−TiO2_x catalysts (Fig 7 , Fig 8 , Table 4 ). The spent catalysts were analyzed to determine the transformation of surface Pd and oxygen after 24 h catalytic reaction. Although the catalysts were pre-reduced at 400 °C to form PdZn alloy, prolonged exposure to a reducing environment during CO2 hydrogenation causes further Pd alloying with Zn. Pd3d spectra for all calcined PdZn/ZnO−TiO2_x showed two peaks of palladium with binding energies of 336.7 eV and 342.1 eV corresponding to Pd3d 5/2 and Pd3d 3/2 orbitals of PdO, respectively. The Pd3d spectra of spent catalysts consisted of two oxidation states at ∼334.7 eV for metallic Pd [54] and ∼336.1 eV for PdZn alloy [55]. Pd in PdZn alloy has greater binding energy than the metallic state due to Pd alloying with Zn, causing a chemical shift to a higher region owing to electron transfer from Pd to Zn [56]. The absence of Pd2+implied that PdO existed on the catalyst fully reduced into Pd0 and the bimetallic PdZn alloy during the reaction. There was no surface oxidation to form PdO when the catalysts were exposed to air during the transfer from the reactor to the XPS analysis. Table 4 summarizes the relative content of Pd species on post-reaction catalysts that generally exhibited a higher level of Pd monometallic than PdZn alloy on all catalysts. The O1s region was examined to elucidate oxygen vacancies by deconvoluting the O1s signal for both calcined and spent PdZn catalysts (Fig 8). After calcination, binding energy at 529.0 eV was ascribed to lattice oxygen of ZnTiO3 or TiO2. The peak at ∼530.2 eV was assigned to surface oxygen vacancy. Oxygen distribution was calculated based on the deconvoluted peak ratio between the oxygen vacancies on the surface and the lattice oxygen. Based on Table 4, calcined PdZn/ZnO−TiO2_x exhibited lattice oxygen dominating over oxygen vacancies. However, surface oxygen vacancy concentration increased on the spent catalysts, with the PdZn/ZnO−TiO2_0.5 exhibiting domination of surface oxygen over the lattice oxygen. The oxygen vacancy for PdZn/ZnO−TiO2_0.5 increased drastically from 29.8% to 70.4% after 24 h reaction, followed by PdZn/ZnO−TiO2_2.0 and PdZn/ZnO−TiO2_1.0. Such high oxygen vacancies could be related to the formation of the cubic ZnTiO3 phase, evident from the XRD patterns of PdZn/ZnO−TiO2_0.5 (Fig 2). Cubic ZnTiO3 showed a high tendency to generate oxygen vacancies from the high density of the terminal Ti3+−OH bond [57]. The formation of oxygen vacancies has a significant role in CO2 hydrogenation. Many studies have highlighted the role of oxygen vacancies in CO2 adsorption and activation [58], formation of reactive intermediates [59], and the promotion of electron transfer to the electron-deficient carbon atom in CO2 [58]. These are necessary steps for the conversion of CO2 to methanol. However, moderate oxygen vacancy levels are required to prevent the increase of energy barrier for reactive intermediates or the weak ability to bind oxygen [59]. 3.8 In-situ drifts analysis In-situ DRIFTS was performed with different reaction temperatures ranging between 200−400 °C and 15 bar to investigate the intermediate species formed during CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. PdZn/ZnO_TiO2_0.5 catalyst was reduced in situ at 400 °C for 1 h prior to the analysis. Fig 9 showed IR spectra of PdZn/ZnO−TiO2_0.5 during CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. The minor peak formed at 2390 cm-1 corresponded to the vibration mode of the C − O bond of gaseous CO2 [60]. IR bands produced at 1482 and 1438 cm-1 correlated to vas (O − C − O) and vs (O − C − O) vibration modes of monodentate carbonate (m-CO3 2-) [61]. At 200 °C, the formation of the intermediate formyl, *HCO, could be observed at 1809 cm-1 as well as bidentate formate, *b-HCOO, at 1595 and 1377 cm-1 relative to both asymmetric and symmetric vibration modes of O − C − O bond [62,63],. The formyl band (1809 cm-1) showed enhanced intensity at 300 °C while the bidentate formate reduced. As the temperature increased to 250 °C, the bands at 1059, 1026 and 1006 cm-1 appeared could be attributed to C − O stretching of methoxy (*CH3O) group of methanol [35,64],. The formaldehyde (*CH2O) absorption band can be seen at 1715 cm-1 assigned to (C = O) vibration [65]. Methanol formation can also be monitored based on the broad band centered at 2940 cm-1 assigned to the asymmetric vibration of C − H [66]. Fig 9.(b) shows the IR region between 3500 and 2500 cm-1 to examine the C − H stretching modes. IR band developed at 2845 cm-1 could be ascribed to the v(CH2) stretching mode of formaldehyde (*CH2O) [64]. The asymmetry C − H stretching modes of methoxy appeared at 2978 and 2943 cm-1, whereas the 2873 and 2814 cm-1 bands are relative to the symmetry mode [67]. The CH band intensity reduced as temperature increased above 350 °C, and disappeared at 400 °C. The peaks formed at 1514, and 1315 cm-1 (Fig 9.(a)) corresponded to asymmetric and symmetric modes of O − C − O of bidentate carbonate. High temperature above 300 °C enhanced CO2 adsorption via interaction with the hydroxyl group to form bidentate carbonate. The bidentate carbonate subsequently decomposed into CO, increasing CO band intensity at 2181 and 2106 cm-1 [17]. The DRIFTS analysis suggests methanol formation followed the formate pathway (*HCOO) at lower temperatures, with subsequent formaldehyde and methoxy formation [68]. However, the stabilization of formyl species at 300 °C indicates the possibility of methanol formation via the RWGS pathway. CO from RWGS reacted with hydrogen spillover to form formyl intermediates (*HCO) before being hydrogenated to methanol [69]. 3.9 Catalytic activity Fig 10 showed catalytic activity over PdZn/ZnO−TiO2_x catalysts at different reaction temperatures ranging from 100−400 °C and pressure 20 bar. The catalysts were reduced in situ at 400 °C to ensure the formation of PdZn alloy before reaction. Overall CO2 conversion for all three catalysts increased exponentially at temperatures above 200 °C. The catalysts exhibited 100% methanol selectivity at temperatures below 150 °C before gradually decreasing as the reaction temperature increased. At lower reaction temperatures, i.e. 100–150 °C, there is only a slight difference in the CO2 conversion between the catalysts. PdZn/ZnO−TiO2_2.0 showed 2.6% CO2 conversion, followed by PdZn/ZnO−TiO2_1.0 with ∼2.4% and PdZn/ZnO−TiO2_0.5 at ∼1.8%. All three catalysts demonstrated 100% selectivity towards methanol formation, indicating no by-products formed below 150 °C. When the reaction temperature increases to 200 °C, there is a significant improvement in the conversion. PdZn/ZnO−TiO2_1.0 catalyst displayed higher CO2 conversion throughout the temperatures and achieved a maximum conversion of 44.6% at 400 °C (Fig 11. a). However, at high temperatures, CO formation reduces methanol selectivity for all three catalysts due to competing reverse-water-gas-shift reaction (RWGS)(Eqn. (2)) [70]. PdZn/ZnO−TiO2_1.0 demonstrates a higher methanol selectivity of 74.7% and 48.9% at 200 °C and 250 °C, respectively with 1267.1 mmolkgcat -1h-1 methanol productivity at 250 °C (Fig 11.b). The conversion and methanol selectivity are comparable with the previously reported data on PdZn and Pd based catalysts at 250 °C (Table 5 ). However, at 300 °C, PdZn/ZnO-TiO2_0.5 produced a higher methanol productivity to give 950 mmolkgcat -1h-1 in comparison with PdZn/ZnO−TiO2_1.0 and PdZn/ZnO−TiO2_2.0. Low reaction temperature and high pressure are required for high CO2 conversion to methanol [71]. Hence, the reduced methanol selectivity as the temperature rose above 250 °C due to the shifting thermodynamic equilibrium, favoring CO formation instead of methanol. Methane was also generated as a by-product at the higher reaction temperature, i.e.,>300 °C, through CO2 methanation. Higher hydrocarbons, such as ethane and propane, were analyzed at higher temperatures, and these higher hydrocarbon chains started to form at 300 °C (Fig S1). Stability studies were conducted at 250 °C and 300 °C to deduce the catalytic performance of the catalysts over 24 h reaction (Fig 12 ). All three catalysts displayed stable methanol productivity at 250 °C. PdZn/ZnO−TiO2_1.0 exhibited higher CO2 conversion ∼12.2% and methanol selectivity ∼51.4% with constant methanol productivity ∼1200 - 1300 mmolkgcat -1h-1 (Fig 12). However, at 300 °C PdZn/ZnO−TiO2_0.5 displayed high methanol productivity with methanol yield gradually increasing from 700 mmolkg-1h-1 to ∼1035.1 mmolkg-1h-1 after 24 h reaction. PdZn/ZnO−TiO2_1.0 produced methanol at 750 mmolkg-1h-1 at the beginning of the reaction and reached 950 mmolkg-1h-1 at 24 h. PdZn/ZnO−TiO2_2.0 produced 470 mmolkg-1h-1 methanol initially and gradually increased to 985 mmolkg-1h-1 after 24 h reaction. XRD and XPS analysis confirmed the formation of PdZn alloy, which is crucial for methanol production from CO2. PdZn alloy stabilizes formate species as a vital intermediate for methanol production. Apart from that, the catalysts also experience structural changes under reduction conditions. SEM showed morphology changes due to cubic/hexagonal ZnTiO3 formation after reduction, further confirmed by XRD. TEM confirms that the ZnTiO3 formed near the PdZn alloy. The hydrogen spillover from Pd presumably caused ZnTiO3 formation, as supported by H2-TPR analysis. Variation of Zn:Ti ratios affected the ZnTiO3 crystalline phase, in which c-ZnTiO3 was formed on low Zn:Ti ratios, while h-ZnTiO3 formed at higher ratios. Raman and XPS analyses provide insight into the presence of oxygen vacancies that might correlate to the ZnTiO3 formation. An aparent enhancement of oxygen vacancies was observed on the post-reaction catalysts. The reaction mechanism can be deduced based on catalytic data, DRIFTS analysis and characterization of the catalysts (Fig 13 ). DRIFTS analysis shows that the formate intermediate formed at 200 °C but decreased at 300 °C, implying methanol formation follows the formate pathway at low temperatures. However, at 300 °C, there is a possibility that methanol formation occurs through formyl intermediates. PdZn/ZnO−TiO2_0.5 showed a higher methanol rate at 300 °C, suggesting methanol produced from the hydrogenation of CO to methanol via formyl intermediates. CO2 is absorbed on the surface via the coordination of carbon atoms with Zn or Ti, forming bidentate formate. In the presence of surface oxygen vacancies, as evidenced by XPS and Raman analysis, the vacant sites were occupied by the O atoms of CO2 [77], weakening the C − O bond. The adsorbed CO was hydrogenated to form formyl (*HCO) species that filled the vacancies with oxygen atoms. Hydrogen dissociation occurs on the PdZn surface, spillover to the surrounding support for CO hydrogenation. The dissociation of the first C − O bond to form formyl (*HCO) strongly relied on the availability of surface oxygen vacancies on the support. At Zn:Ti = 0.5, a high density of surface oxygen vacancies, presumably generated due to the formation of cubic ZnTiO3 phase, accelerate C − O bond dissociation. Formyl species are stabilized by interaction with PdZn sites through the Metal−CHO bond [78], before proceeding to the consecutive hydrogenation generating methoxy species and finally methanol (*CO → *HCO → *CH2O → *CH3O → CH3OH) [79]. 5 Conclusion Investigation of the effect of Zn:Ti ratios on the catalytic activity of PdZn alloy showed that optimization towards methanol productivity was achieved. Different compositions of ZnO and TiO2 affected the formation of cubic and hexagonal ZnTiO3 crystal structures. A high Zn:Ti ratio forms a mixture of cubic and hexagonal ZnTiO3 crystallites, while only cubic ZnTiO3 was observed at a low Zn:Ti ratio. As seen in the SEM analysis, the elongated C-axis ZnTiO3 implied the incorporation of a higher degree of Zn in the crystal structure. XPS and Raman analysis confirmed the formation of surface oxygen vacancies following PdZn alloy formation which can be correlated with the formation of ZnTiO3. Oxygen vacancies are favorable on low Zn:Ti ratios due to the formation of cubic ZnTiO3. It is worth mentioning that all CO2 hydrogenation products, such as methanol, methane and CO, require the formation of surface oxygen vacancies to provide adsorption and dissociation sites for CO2. However, in order to perform direct CO2 hydrogenation to methanol, as observed on the DRIFTS spectra, the catalyst must form bidentate carbonate that subsequently produces formate, formaldehyde and methoxy species. High surface oxygen vacancy density might allow methanol formation via formyl intermediates at high reaction temperatures. Hydrogenation of CO to form formyl requires oxygen vacancies near PdZn alloy. coredata.dc:description: Porous ZnO−TiO2 synthesized using different Zn and Ti ratios (Zn:Ti = 0.5, 1, 2) is investigated as PdZn alloy support to optimize methanol production from CO2 hydrogenation. XRD, Raman, and XPS analyses reveal that varying Zn ratios influence crystal structure, oxygen vacancies, surface area and ZnTiO3 phases. The partial transformation into ZnTiO3 occurs on the PdZn perimeter, forming strong interfacial interaction with the PdZn alloy. Higher Zn content promotes hexagonal ZnTiO3, while lower ratios favor cubic ZnTiO3, which leads to higher oxygen vacancy formation. High methanol selectivity was obtained below 250 °C with optimum productivity at ∼1326.8 mmolkgcat -1h-1. CO is the main product at temperatures above 250 °C, while methane and C2+hydrocarbons from the C − C coupling reaction occur at 450 °C. In-situ DRIFTS analysis provides insight into the reaction mechanism that requires stabilization of formate *HCOO and formyl species, *HCO, for hydrogenation to methanol.
